com.danielvizzini.util
Class MiscUtil

java.lang.Object
  com.danielvizzini.util.MiscUtil

public class MiscUtil
extends java.lang.Object

Kitchen sink of static methods with iterables as parameters to be used in multiple projects, kept in one place to avoid code drift.

findConstructor

public static <T> java.lang.reflect.Constructor<T> findConstructor(java.lang.Class<T> klass,
                                                                   java.lang.Class<?>... parameterTypes)
                                                        throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
Returns the constructor of a class given its parameters. Used instead of getConstructor because of that will not handle parameters with generics.

Parameters:
klass - the class for the constructor sought
parameterTypes - parameter types of constructor returned
Returns:
constructor that constructs and instance of klass using the parameters specified
Throws:
java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - if the constructor specified does not exist

Returns an enum instance given the enum class and the name of the instance. Similar to Enum.valueOf() but case insensitive

Parameters:
enumeration - Enum class (e.g. DaysOfWeek.class)
name - name of enum instance, regardless of case (e.g. "MoNdAy")
Returns:
the enum instance (e.g. MONDAY)

greatestCommonDivisor

public static int greatestCommonDivisor(java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Integer> integers)
Calculates the greatest common divisor of an array using Euclid's method. Thank you Euclid.

Parameters:
integers - Iterable of integers, can be negative or positive and in any order
Returns:
the greatest common divisor of all elements of the array

If the array is all zeros the greatest common divisor will be zero, and not the more mathematically correct infinity

greatestCommonDivisor

public static int greatestCommonDivisor(int[] integers)
Calculates the greatest common divisor of an array using Euclid's method. Thank you Euclid.

Parameters:
integers - array of integers, can be negative or positive and in any order
Returns:
the greatest common divisor of all elements of the array

If the array is all zeros the greatest common divisor will be zero, and not the more mathematically correct infinity

greatestCommonDivisor

public static int greatestCommonDivisor(int firstInteger,
                                        int secondInteger)
Calculates the greatest common divisor using Euclid's method

Parameters:
firstInteger - any integer, can be negative or positive, greater or smaller than second
secondInteger - any integer, can be negative or positive, greater or smaller than first
Returns:
the greatest common divisor of firstInteger and secondInteger

If both parameters are zero the greatest common divisor will be zero, and not the more mathematically correct infinity

modPositive

public static int modPositive(int integer,
                              int modulus)
Parameters:
integer - the integer that one is applying the modulus operator to
modulus - the base of the modulus operator
Returns:
integer % modulus, set to be positive
Examples:
modPositive(17, 5) == 2//true
modPositive(17, -5) == 2//true
modPositive(-17, 5) == 3//true
modPositive(-17, -5) == 3//true

Parameters:

Parameters:

Returns:

getLongestString

public static java.lang.String getLongestString(java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String> stringList)
Parameters:
stringList - list of strings
Returns:
longest string. If iterable is empty, "" is returned. If two strings are equally long, the first is returned.
